Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story:
I stared at my phone, rereading my stepmother’s message: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It would mean so much to your dad.” My heart thudded. I knew how important these traditions were to my family, especially since I’d joined them. They wanted me to step up, to show I belonged, to honor the rituals that made us whole. But my laptop pinged with another Slack notification—QA had flagged the UI glitch again. It wasn’t critical, but users were getting confused, and my manager expected a fix by tomorrow. I could almost hear his voice: “We need you on this, you’re the only one who understands that module.” 

I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of my family’s hopes pressing on one shoulder, the responsibility to my team on the other. If I focused on the ceremony, I’d let my colleagues down. If I dove into the code, I’d disappoint my family, maybe even widen the gap I’d worked so hard to close. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more.
